You look around the room and observe the hands in the air. {ifStateCondition|composure lt 3|You feel uncertainty tug at you as your hands twitch. You hope you can survive the questions.|Oh well, you'll take what you can get.}
You lean back, feeling the relief and exhaustion end of time brings.

choiceLabel: Call on the student whose hand shot up high above her head.
content: You call on {name|enthusiasticStudent} for perhaps the fifth time, and brace yourself for her explosive enthusiasm. She leans forward, hands gesturing furiously as she says, "So, I read that artificial carbon sequestion is a thing now - isn't that great? Wouldn't taking carbdon dioxide out of the atmosphere help with the acidity of the ocean?"

You find yourself hesitating. There is an eagerness in {name|enthusiasticStudent}'s eyes, a positivity that you might have lost amidst the research surrounding the rise in carbon dioxide - something you can't help but want to cling too. Yet there is also a naivety in her words that gives you pause.

{ifStateCondition|composure gte 5|Looking around at all the bored and unconvinced faces, you decide to say,|You have absolutely no idea how to tell Élika that she's got some of her facts wrong, so you stammer out a general} "That is an excellent point, Élika. Carbon capture and storage is likely to reduce fossil fuel emissions by quite a lot, which would help with the acidity rise in the oceans."

{name|enthusiasticStudent} beams, though you notice faces that aren't as happy.

choiceLabel: It's actually a bit more complicated than that.
content:
{ifStateCondition|composure gte 5|"It's not exactly taking carbon dioxide out of the air itself - it's capturing the CO2 at the energy plants before it's released into the atmosphere," you explain. "Carbon capture actually takes a significant amount of energy - which would mean some of a plant's regular output would be lost."

Élika's face turns thoughtful. |"See, carbon capture - like, the actual capturing of... carbon... that is, taking it from um, the gas, or the coal itself, you know, at the factories - the power plants, sorry - takes a lot of energy - oh, and CCS is actually done inside power plants." You halt awkwardly. "Yeah."

Élika blinks at you. Then blinks again. "...huh?"}

choiceLabel: No, you've got your facts completely wrong.
content: "If we could physically take the CO2 out of our atmosphere like a tree does, that would be spectacular," you say. "But no, it's actually done at the power plants, either before or after the coal gets burned - it would take a lot of energy, reducing the plant's output, which is not what our energy-hungry country wants right now."

"And frankly," you continue, "it would be way better if we stuck to cleaner energies that already exist then trying to make coal 'clean'."

{name|enthusiasticStudent}'s smile had faded from her face a long time ago. As well as many others'.
{name|enthusiasticStudent} looks like she wants to ask another question. Take it?
You check the time. {ifStateCondition|composure lt 3|Your heart jumps in your chest. You're running out of time.|A good place to move on, you decide.} You look around the room for more questions.
"So," {name|enthusiasticStudent} says, "do you think we'll be able to stop the acidity from rising?"

"I mean, we've already come so far with technology and science," you say. "I'm sure that now that we are aware of the problems too much CO2 is causing we can fix them."

{name|enthusiasticStudent}'s eyes brighten.'

"As far as we've come with technology and science, change takes course over a long period of time," you say. "We'll have to undo a lot of effects we've already made, and sometimes fixing's more difficult to do."
{name|enthusiasticStudent} looks down, but is nodding in what you hope is understanding.

"I mean, if you think about it, we've come so far with technology and science that a lot of damage has already been done," you say. "Not to mention it's hard giving up the comfort and convenience of things like cars to try and make a difference in the amount of CO2 we already release daily."

{name|enthusiasticStudent} avoids your gaze.

choiceLabel: Call on the student whose hand hesitantly hovers halfway up in the air.
content: {name|shyStudent} looks ready to crawl under their desk when your attention turns to them. "U-um, uh, I- I get that the ac- that the rise in acidity is a problem, but..." they gesture, as if trying to pluck the right word from the air. "What can we do about it?"

Their eyes fall upon their desk. "Even if more people ride bikes or whatever, there are still so many cars pumping all that carbon dioxide into the air - sometimes I look out the window and just see the millions of cars in traffic and think, 'Geez, we've gone too far to turn back now. No one wants to give up their car.'"

"True, the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere is making a noticeable impact on our planet," you say. "But we're acknowledging these problems, right?

For example, did you know that 16.9% of energy generation in 2016 comes from renewable energy? Which may not seem much until you compare it to the 13% just the year before.

You smile at {name|shyStudent}. "We're making progress, and that's the most important thing to hold on to. After all, if we just stop doing anything because it's hopeless, we'll never change. Then there's zero chance anything will get better."

"It's not looking good for us, sadly. {ifStateCondition|composure lt 3|Humans are selfish, greedy creatures who won't make a lick of different because we're too busy thinking about ourselves without even realizing that this is impacting us too!|Even if we were to suddenly stop emitting greenhouse gases, the earth would still warm about a degree Farenheit, so...}"

You stop abruptly, noticing {name|shyStudent}'s face crumple.

choiceLabel: Don't be such a downer, kid.
content:
"That attitude is the reason change is so slow - it's because we sit around complaining about how we've ruined things instead of actually cleaning up the mess."

You notice {name|shyStudent} shrinking back. You may have been a little too harsh. And unprofessional. Whoops.

{ifStateCondition|composure gte 5|"The point is," you continue, a bit more gently, "Change is still possible. Keep your chin up."|"The point is," you say, fumbling a bit, "We can still do something about it. We just need to - well, actually do something."}
{name|shyStudent} looks like they have another question. Take it? Or call on another student?
"So, um," comes {name|shyStudent}'s soft voice. "Then - what can <i>I</> do?"

"Teach yourself about what's going on and how you can help - and teach others. There are the little things you hear about, like recycling and the like, and other things like volunteering at beaches. There's also the path of becoming a professor," you say. Like me, you think.

choiceLabel: Find out what you can do within your community.
content: "Volunteer, donate, see what your local issues are, participate in local politics - sometimes it's best to start small in a place you know best." You can't help but remember Shelly lecturing you about this.

"We're all doomed," you helpfully inform them. "No matter what you do."

{name|shyStudent} doesn't look particularly inspired.
